Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Empowering Citizen Scientists to Monitor Environmental Waterborne Pathogens by DotLens Smartphone Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

PI: Shih, Wei-Chuan

Proposal No 1643391

It is proposed to use imaging capability of smartphone as a microscope for detecting and measuring waterborne parasite in surface waters. A smartphone microscopy kit for environmental water quality monitoring of two waterborne pathogens, Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum will be developed. Both high school teachers and students in high school will be taught on sampling, measurement and analysis of water samples.

It is proposed to use the imaging capability of smartphone as a microscope by adding a simple polymeric lens that will bridge the gap between macro and micro imaging. The lens coupled with a simple microscope state and image processing app will enable resolution of 2-3 microns. The parasites being three to two times larger, can be resolved on a fixed position microscope stage. An image processing software in the form of an app will make for an easy interface for the user. Details of a smartphone microscopy kit for environmental water quality monitoring of two waterborne pathogens, Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum will be developed, and disseminated via various methods. The imaging approach simplifies the measurement of parasites. Also cross-platform tools and methods that can be replicated by citizen scientists using any smartphone will also be developed. Successful monitoring of the pathogenic species can potentially contribute to community public health management and prevent disease outbreaks. The capability of performing high-quality microscopy using a smartphone will find other applications in biology, biomedicine, and environmental science and technology, and K-12 STEM education. The simplicity of the proposed smartphone microscope will enable citizen scientists to replicate and create their own experiments and measurements. The project has a strong outreach and education component, covering K-12 STEM education and research participation by undergraduate students and teachers. The PI will collaborate with Alief Independent School District on piloting a smartphone microscopy based curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optical microscopy has been a ubiquitous tool in a broad range of scientific research such as biology, biomedicine, chemistry, physics, and materials. However, traditional microscopy instruments are bulky, costly, and require skilled personnel to operate, which have severely limited the applications of microscopy inside controlled laboratory environment. In other words, in order for any specimen to be imaged under a microscope, it has to be sampled, prepared, and physically transported to a laboratory. For many scientific or non-scientific applications, such a protocol is prohibitively costly, or simply not feasible. 

In recent years, significant efforts have been devoted to “democratizing” microscopy, partly due to the trend of portable and wearable devices, consumer electronics, and most prominently, the extremely rapid adoption rate of smartphones globally. Smartphone microscopy has incarnated in a variety of design embodiments, and their multi-modality capabilities have been demonstrated. Among them, the PI’s laboratory developed a novel smartphone microscope that requires a single additional lens. Dubbed “DotLens”, a tiny piece of transparent silicone rubber can be directly put on the camera window without external support, in a fashion similar to how contact lenses are worn. This lens then turns the smartphone camera into a microscope with demonstrated spatial resolution ~1 µm. Such a device is readily capable of bright-field microscopy using ambient light. The first paper we published in Journal of Biomedical Optics in May 2015 was the #1 downloaded paper of that journal with >10,000 downloads. 

We further utilized consumer grade 3D printer to fabricate a dark chamber right in front of the DotLens and demonstrated both dark-field and fluorescence microscopy using battery-powered light emitting diodes (LEDs). The entire design of this device has been published together with performance benchmarking and applications in Biomedical Optics Express. The paper became the #1 downloaded paper of that journal in 2018 and has been downloaded for more than 5,000 times since its publication in November 2017.

Here we briefly discuss three major applications demonstrated in the paper: (1) autofluorescence from microalgae; (2) fluorescence stains for live/dead discrimination in bacteria and (3) immunofluorescence for waterborne pathogen identification and quantification. 

1. Autofluorescence: The LED illumination ensures wide incident angles and allows a portion of the TIR-guided light to couple into the water film and excite fluorescence from suspended Spirogyra algae with salient filamentous and helical structures Fluorescence imaging was performed with blue LEDs (λLED = 465 nm) and a red filter (λCUT-ON = 600 nm). The configuration was compatible with the fluorescence excitation / emission of chlorophyll (a, b) which has excitation peaks in the blue wavelength (430, 453 nm), and emission peaks in the red wavelength (662, 642 nm). The image contrast was found to be 0.45 due to light attenuation by the filter. However, the fluorescence imaging modality selectively highlights the chlorophyll-rich helical structures against the chlorophyll-free cell wall structures. 

2. Binding stains: Bacterial viability studies are important for developing bacterial control procedures to limit bacterial infection, and to understand surface contamination and biofilm formation. The development of fluorescent stains would enable rapid imaging-based viability tests compared to conventional assays based on cell culture or metabolic characterization. Following standard staining protocols, two contrasting nucleic acid stains were used for bacterial viability tests: SYTO 9 can penetrate both intact and compromised cell membranes, while propidium iodide (PI) can only penetrate compromised cell membranes. The prepared samples were imaged by the smartphone with blue LED (λLED = 465 nm) and green filter (λCUT-ON = 515 nm) for SYTO 9, and with green LED (λLED = 520 nm) and red filter (λCUT-ON= 625 nm) for PI. A particle counting algorithm based on intensity thresholding with watershed was used to obtain total bacteria as nall = 885 and ndead = 54, or equivalently, nlive = 831 (93.9%). 

3. Immunofluorescence for waterborne pathogens: Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum are waterborne parasites that cause gastroenteritis and are commonly found in public water bodies. Frequent outbreaks of both highlight the importance of constant water monitoring procedures. Morphologically, G. lamblia is a larger oval-shaped parasite (~10 μm), and C. parvum is a smaller circular parasite (~5 μm). A mixture of both parasites and 6 μm PS beads was dried on a glass slide. The PS beads were included as a potential confounding factor for comparison. The glass slide was subsequently immersed in an aqueous solution of antibody-conjugated-fluorescein that specifically binds to antigenic sites found only in G. lamblia and C. parvum membranes followed by DI water rinse. The high specificity of the immunofluorescence stain enabled the parasites to be identified and counted, for quick on-site applications in citizen science.
